item.title: Coding and Recoding Scaled Items
item.description:
• Book Stuff

Book Stuff

You may recall a prerequisite for this course was one semester of graduate statistics. Since many of you used SPSS or some other GUI based statistical software, the documents below were purposely chosen to help in a review process. The skills outlined below reflect much of what is taught in a traditional introductory statistics course and are necessary to understand the remaining content. Starting next week, we begin learning additional approaches that are used in survey analysis.

  • Read/review a part of Chapter 4: Constructing a Survey in Stockemer

  • Review this Prezi presentation on Item Response Theory (IRT). We will cover both exploratory factor analysis (EFA) and IRT next week.

item.title: The Fundamentals of Writing Questions
item.description:
• Article
  • Book Stuff

Article

Read1 Material Incentives and Other Potential Factors Associated With Response Rates to Internet Surveys of American Evaluation Association Members: Findings From a Randomized Experiment by Coryn CLS, Becho LW, Westine CD, Mateu PF, Abu-Obaid RN, Hobson KA, Schröter DC, Dodds EL, Vo AT & Ramlow M.2

Book Stuff

Read Chapter 4: The Fundamentals of Writing Questions in Dillman, Smyth, and Christian.

  1. This is a mostly new publication and is copyright protected so you will have to login with your WVU MIX account to access it.↩︎

  2. Full disclosure: I serve on the American Evaluation Association Survey Workgroup that creates the annual survey outlined in the article. Additionally many of the authors on the paper are friends and colleagues and some were also in my doctoral cohort. Regardless, you will be able to see the breakdown of a mass survey administered to a large audience, some of which could inform your upcoming survey design and administration.↩︎

item.title: Web Questionnaires and Implementation
item.description:
• Book Stuff

Book Stuff

Read Chapter 9: Web Questionnaires and Implementation in Dillman, Smyth, and Christian1

  1. We are skipping Chapter 8: Telephone Questionnaires and Implementation since as of this writing, a study by the CDC using second half 2019 data found that of U.S. households, 61.3% report having only wireless phones, 2.4% were landline only, and 1.0% were without either. With that said, it may be in your interest to read Chapter 8 since the same study also found that 37.2% of households have both, though this estimate has been declining rapidly over the past four years. Regardless while the ability to reach a large audience will likely become diminish soon, currently plenty of people can still be reached using this traditional mode.↩︎
